headline: Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2018
componenttextpreview: Doug, from a capital allocation standpoint, could you discuss a little bit about closing the 63 Sam's stores earlier? And then should we expect to see continued closings both in the U.S. and International? And then for Brett, on the digital side, could yo
componenttext: Doug, from a capital allocation standpoint, could you discuss a little bit about closing the 63 Sam's stores earlier? And then should we expect to see continued closings both in the U.S. and International? And then for Brett, on the digital side, could you shed some light on the growth between 1P and 3P for the e-com business?

headline: Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take capital allocation first. If you go back a couple of years, you'll remember that we closed quite a few stores around the world, including the 100-some-odd Express stores in Walmart U.S., the smaller stores that we have been testing as a pi
componenttext: Sure. I'll take capital allocation first. If you go back a couple of years, you'll remember that we closed quite a few stores around the world, including the 100-some-odd Express stores in Walmart U.S., the smaller stores that we have been testing as a pilot -- as a format. We discontinued those and closed those. At that moment in time, we had been through all of the 11,600-plus units around the world, sitting through real estate, meeting, Brett, country by country and making choices about the portfolio. So we did a lot of that cleanup then. We didn't do Sam's Club at the time. We were still working through a number of things, pacing things out, trying to put them in the right sequence. So the way I was thinking of it is let's make sure that the U.S. store business is strong. What do we need to make that work? That's where we made wage investments, price investments and cleaned up the portfolio. We've been focused on -- focusing on building an e-commerce business. That's still underway obviously. And then now we've turned our attention to Sam's Club. We've got a strategy we believe in, a leadership team we're excited about, and we're investing in that business to drive comps up there. So it's just been a sequencing, and the bottom line is we've been through the portfolio. I can't tell you there will never be more closings. A store here and there, I think, makes sense, but we've been through the majority of that big work for now anyway.

headline: Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2018
componenttextpreview: Chuck, on your question of 1P and 3P, obviously, first part, they're part -- they're both important to us. We want to satisfy that customer need. Sometimes, it's better done through first party; sometimes, it's better done through third party. As you know
componenttext: Chuck, on your question of 1P and 3P, obviously, first part, they're part -- they're both important to us. We want to satisfy that customer need. Sometimes, it's better done through first party; sometimes, it's better done through third party. As you know, we have about 75 million SKUs now on our Marketplace site. And it's another one of those levers that we've talked about -- I was talking about earlier that we have in order to determine how we best fulfill that customer need in a way that makes sense for both top line and bottom line.

headline: Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, guys. We certainly appreciate you joining our call today, and have a great day.
componenttext: Well, thanks, guys. We certainly appreciate you joining our call today, and have a great day.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to Walmart's Fiscal Year 2019 Third Quarter Earnings Release. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.I'd now like to turn the conference over to Dan Binder, Vice President of Investor Relations. P
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to Walmart's Fiscal Year 2019 Third Quarter Earnings Release. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I'd now like to turn the conference over to Dan Binder, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, Mr. Binder.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Walmart's investor relations call to discuss third quarter earnings. This is Dan Binder, and I'm joined today by Kary Brunner, James Mann, Michael Brigance and Shirish Gupta from our IR team. Hopefully, you've had some time to
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Walmart's investor relations call to discuss third quarter earnings. This is Dan Binder, and I'm joined today by Kary Brunner, James Mann, Michael Brigance and Shirish Gupta from our IR team. Hopefully, you've had some time to review our press release this morning along with our other Q3 earnings documents. I'll hit on some key points and then we'll open it up to Q&A.
As a reminder, our Q3 earnings press release, management commentary and accompanying slide presentations are available on the Investor page of our corporate website, stock.walmart.com. We may make forward-looking statements during this call. Please review the Q3 earnings presentation for a cautionary statement regarding forward-looking statements.
In terms of key takeaways, we had good quarter with strength in many areas of the business. On a constant-currency basis, net revenue was up 2.4% or $2.9 billion year-over-year and exceeded plan. On a reported basis, this was just under $125 billion in revenue and currency negatively affected the top line by about $1.2 billion and operating profit by nearly $60 million. Adjusted EPS was $1.08 per share and that was about an 8% increase over last year. From a GAAP perspective, we posted $0.58.
Now let me give you a little bit of color on sales. We continue to see strong momentum in the Walmart U.S. business with both comp transactions and comp ticket growth. As you saw, Q3 comps were, in the U.S., up 3.4%, and on a 2-year stack basis, were up 6.1%. It has been well over 10 years since we have seen back-to-back quarters with 2-year stack comps above 6%, so we're pleased with the momentum in the business.
At the time of our last call, we were about halfway through the back-to-school season, and I told you that we were seeing a strength in that business. I'm pleased to say that the season wrapped up with solid results, and then we ended the quarter with strong sales of fall seasonal goods, including Halloween. While we don't break out grocery comps specifically, I will tell you that it was the best 2-year stack comp in nearly 9 years. I just wanted to point out that the hurricanes last year obviously provided us with some tough compares in that category, and we were pleased with the momentum despite that tough comparison and particularly with fresh.
As you also saw in today's release, U.S. e-commerce sales grew 43%, keeping us on track to achieve about 40% growth for the year. We also continue to see good top line results for International and Sam's Club. 9 of the 10 international markets reported positive comps, led by Mexico. In Sam's Club, we saw reported strong comp store sales growth of 3.2% excluding fuel, and 5.7% excluding fuel and tobacco. Sam's Club e-commerce sales grew 32%, and we continue to be pleased with membership trends.
Lastly, as detailed in our release, we did raise our Walmart U.S. comp store sales guidance executable from around 3% to at least 3%. We're now expecting full-year adjusted EPS of $4.75 to $4.85, which was raised from our previous guidance of $4.65 to $4.80. Just in terms of a reminder, I'd like to remind you that we report fourth quarter earnings on Tuesday, February 19, 2019. In addition, we have posted our fiscal year 2020 earnings releases -- release dates on our IR website.
So with that, I'm happy to open up the call to your questions. Operator, if we could get started. Thanks.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Peter Benedict with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Peter Benedict with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So maybe 2 questions. One, Sam's had 27% private brand penetration, I think that was like 23-or-so a year ago. So I'm just curious, what's driving -- which categories are driving the increased private brand penetration there? And how does that penetration
componenttext: So maybe 2 questions. One, Sam's had 27% private brand penetration, I think that was like 23-or-so a year ago. So I'm just curious, what's driving -- which categories are driving the increased private brand penetration there? And how does that penetration compare at Walmart U.S.? And maybe the trend that you're seeing in Walmart U.S.? That's my first question.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So private brand has, in fact, moving up. As you know, we consolidated down to 1 private brand at Sam's Club, and we've really seen strength in many areas of the club. We don't break it out specifically, but it was pretty broad-based. And then
componenttext: Yes, sure. So private brand has, in fact, moving up. As you know, we consolidated down to 1 private brand at Sam's Club, and we've really seen strength in many areas of the club. We don't break it out specifically, but it was pretty broad-based. And then in terms of Walmart U.S., we don't break out private brands specifically, but it has been trending up, and that is not -- I think the takeaway here is it's not because we're really pushing it as much as the customer is really accepting it and responding to the higher quality, the price points, better packaging, et cetera, so nice trend there as well.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up would be, is there any additional color you can provide on Flipkart and how it impacted the various line items in the P&L, whether it'd be revenue? Is there a -- is it safe to assume that Flipkart was dilutive to gross margin?
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up would be, is there any additional color you can provide on Flipkart and how it impacted the various line items in the P&L, whether it'd be revenue? Is there a -- is it safe to assume that Flipkart was dilutive to gross margin? Just any kind of color you can provide on Flipkart would be great.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, unfortunately, we're not breaking out a lot of detail. I think you heard from Brett at the Investment Community Meeting, we're going to try and give you color over time on how it's doing, high-level, but for competitive reasons, we're not providing a
componenttext: Yes, unfortunately, we're not breaking out a lot of detail. I think you heard from Brett at the Investment Community Meeting, we're going to try and give you color over time on how it's doing, high-level, but for competitive reasons, we're not providing a lot of disclosure on that piece of the business, but it was dilutive, as you can see in our operating margin. And that's all I can say on it at this point. We did have a Great Billion Dollar Day with strength in mobile, smartphones, record turnouts, so we're pleased with that event.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Karen Short with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Karen Short with Barclays.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So I just want to go to earnings guidance implied for the fourth quarter. So there's a lot of one-times that were in last year's third quarter and a lot of one-times that were in last year's fourth quarter, so I'm trying to back all of those out. But when
componenttext: So I just want to go to earnings guidance implied for the fourth quarter. So there's a lot of one-times that were in last year's third quarter and a lot of one-times that were in last year's fourth quarter, so I'm trying to back all of those out. But when I look at the implied EPS guidance for 4Q and try to back into it, that would mean for EBIT, I get EBIT in 4Q down quite a bit more than it was in 3Q, and this again, is on an adjusted apples-to-apples basis, so I'm kind of backing into 10-plus percent, 15% down year-over-year EBIT. Is that -- am I kind of ballpark in that? And then, I guess, if that's the case, why would it actually get worse in 4Q versus 3Q?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: That number sounds high. I'm happy to get into the details of it after the call, but we did have Flipkart in the current quarter for only 44 days just because it's, like many of the other countries with the exception of Canada, it's a 1-month lag. So you
componenttext: That number sounds high. I'm happy to get into the details of it after the call, but we did have Flipkart in the current quarter for only 44 days just because it's, like many of the other countries with the exception of Canada, it's a 1-month lag. So you have 44 days of Flipkart this quarter. The next quarter, obviously, have a full quarter of Flipkart. So that would really be the only callout that I would make. But again, I'm happy to get into the line items postcall.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then so my second question just on Flipkart. So we're looking at what the gross margin deterioration was in International. I mean, you call it, obviously, you call out the fact that the deterioration was primarily a function of having Flipkart i
componenttext: Okay. And then so my second question just on Flipkart. So we're looking at what the gross margin deterioration was in International. I mean, you call it, obviously, you call out the fact that the deterioration was primarily a function of having Flipkart in the quarter, but as we look to 4Q, should we kind of take the run rate that you had in 3Q? And kind of adjust it for only being a 44-day impact in 3Q as we think about 4Q gross margins?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we gave you some guidance at the time of the deal. We updated the guidance at the Investment Community Meeting, indicating we expected about $0.25 of dilution from Flipkart. Well we didn't specifically break it out here in Q3, that guidance has no
componenttext: Yes. So we gave you some guidance at the time of the deal. We updated the guidance at the Investment Community Meeting, indicating we expected about $0.25 of dilution from Flipkart. Well we didn't specifically break it out here in Q3, that guidance has not changed, so you should expect sequentially, you're going to have more dilution in the International profit number on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: My first question on the U.S. EBIT. Last year, I think it was on the commentary, there was $150 million callout of a negative impact to EBIT from hurricanes. And so my first question is, what's the right way to look at the comparison? Because if we add ba
componenttext: My first question on the U.S. EBIT. Last year, I think it was on the commentary, there was $150 million callout of a negative impact to EBIT from hurricanes. And so my first question is, what's the right way to look at the comparison? Because if we add back EBIT to last year's U.S., it would show EBIT for this year down a little with margin down. If we take it out, it paints a slightly different picture, it shows it up and margin up, so I don't know how if there's a nuance the way we should be looking at it?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So you're correct. We did break out some color last year on the hurricanes. We obviously got hit again with some hurricanes this year, so there was expense related to that for all kinds of things, including equipment rental and so forth, but we didn't qua
componenttext: So you're correct. We did break out some color last year on the hurricanes. We obviously got hit again with some hurricanes this year, so there was expense related to that for all kinds of things, including equipment rental and so forth, but we didn't quantify it this year. So it's really kind of hard for me to give you a perfect comparison, but just there was definitely some noise in the number this year as well.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on -- a sales question. So grocery, you don't give us the exact comp, but you told us that the 2-year stack was the best, but we do know it moderated from, I think, mid-single to low single and your ecom business did accelerate, it's up to
componenttext: Okay. And then on -- a sales question. So grocery, you don't give us the exact comp, but you told us that the 2-year stack was the best, but we do know it moderated from, I think, mid-single to low single and your ecom business did accelerate, it's up to 40 -- growth at 43. Bear with me on this inference, but is it fair to say that the nongrocery part of your ecom business is accelerating? Is that a reasonable conclusion?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So we don't break that out specifically, but the color I would add is that the mid-single that you saw in our documents last quarter versus the low single that you see in the documents today for grocery, there was some rounding, so we just characterized t
componenttext: So we don't break that out specifically, but the color I would add is that the mid-single that you saw in our documents last quarter versus the low single that you see in the documents today for grocery, there was some rounding, so we just characterized this quarter as strong -- at the stronger end of low single. And on a 2-year stack, we called that out in particular because we wanted to highlight obviously that we have this hurricane comparison a year ago, but make sure you all understood that, that business continues to have really good momentum, and we've seen good share gains there.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Bob Drbul with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Bob Drbul with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just address a little bit. I think on the ticket growth, did inflation play a factor there? And I was wondering maybe you can give us a little bit more color on the ticket growth. And the second question that I have, there is
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just address a little bit. I think on the ticket growth, did inflation play a factor there? And I was wondering maybe you can give us a little bit more color on the ticket growth. And the second question that I have, there is some discussion on taking market share in key categories. Just wondering if you might be able to line up for us exactly what categories you feel like you're taking the most share currently.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So to answer your question on the ticket, that was not a factor of inflation. We have seen some cost input increases, but similar to last quarter. That's largely been offset by price investment, which, as you can see in our gross margin, continues to
componenttext: Yes. So to answer your question on the ticket, that was not a factor of inflation. We have seen some cost input increases, but similar to last quarter. That's largely been offset by price investment, which, as you can see in our gross margin, continues to be a factor, in fact, the leading factor for gross margin pressure. The reason for ticket improvement, I think, is a function of a few things: one, Online Grocery continues to grow rapidly and that is a significantly higher ticket than the average; second, e-commerce also continues to grow rapidly and that is a higher ticket. And then even if you look within the store, fresh is higher ticket, that's been a leading comp category within grocery. And then you saw some strength in areas like apparel, toys and automotive, so good general merchandise mix as well. So those are really -- that would really sort of sum it up. Do you have a follow-up?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the follow-up is just -- and so, when you look at sort of the market share in key categories, I'd be curious to see your take on that. You're gaining some share, but maybe if you can just comment on the toy category and sort of how you feel l
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the follow-up is just -- and so, when you look at sort of the market share in key categories, I'd be curious to see your take on that. You're gaining some share, but maybe if you can just comment on the toy category and sort of how you feel like you're positioned over the next 60 days.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So for competitive reasons, we wouldn't get too detailed in the market share data, but when we look at Nielsen and the NPD Group, it is very clear that we are gaining share in multiple categories. I highlighted grocery a minute ago, that's been a trend. Y
componenttext: So for competitive reasons, we wouldn't get too detailed in the market share data, but when we look at Nielsen and the NPD Group, it is very clear that we are gaining share in multiple categories. I highlighted grocery a minute ago, that's been a trend. You can see where others are reporting grocery comps versus ours in recent quarters, but it's pretty broad-based. You can see that always had a strong quarter, Bob.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Paul Troxel with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Paul Troxel with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just maybe get a better handle around the adjusted guidance. So the at least 3% growth from a U.S. comp standpoint could imply just the 2 comp at the low end. Is that how we should think about the framework of what the EPS guidance is based on
componenttext: I wanted to just maybe get a better handle around the adjusted guidance. So the at least 3% growth from a U.S. comp standpoint could imply just the 2 comp at the low end. Is that how we should think about the framework of what the EPS guidance is based on? Or any other kind of puts and takes you can help us out with on the adjusted guidance.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So there is nuance there, obviously, and that was -- we wanted to send a message that we're feeling good about the business and, to your point, if you were at 3, you'd probably at about a 2 comp in Q4. I just, hopefully, you took away from my c
componenttext: Yes, sure. So there is nuance there, obviously, and that was -- we wanted to send a message that we're feeling good about the business and, to your point, if you were at 3, you'd probably at about a 2 comp in Q4. I just, hopefully, you took away from my comments earlier that we started the quarter strong, we ended it strong. There's momentum in the business so there's a lot of sales still in front of us but we feel good about the business right now. So we do want to make a slight change to the sales guidance and so we took the earnings up as well.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it. And on gross margins, there's some puts and takes there. You all were lapping the hurricane impact but you did kind of speak to ongoing kind of pricing investments. All plan, it sounds like, but also ongoing increases in transportation cos
componenttext: Got it. Got it. And on gross margins, there's some puts and takes there. You all were lapping the hurricane impact but you did kind of speak to ongoing kind of pricing investments. All plan, it sounds like, but also ongoing increases in transportation costs. Just any additional color you can maybe help us with on what's taking place there.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I had a chance to really look at the walk year-over-year and the 3 things that I called out, explain all of it, I mean, it's really very straightforward. You get heavy price investment. As I think I've probably described to you in the past, that's
componenttext: Yes. So I had a chance to really look at the walk year-over-year and the 3 things that I called out, explain all of it, I mean, it's really very straightforward. You get heavy price investment. As I think I've probably described to you in the past, that's kind of like religion around here. It's very consistent, it's very persistent, it's working, customers are responding, that productivity loop is working for us, transportation costs, no big surprises. That's been pressured throughout the year, continues to be. And then that mix of e-commerce would be the last piece.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Greg Melich with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Greg Melich with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I'll just start with maybe e-commerce. The 43% growth, going back to that, how much of a driver was the grocery pickup rollout? Was that a majority of the ecom growth?
componenttext: I'll just start with maybe e-commerce. The 43% growth, going back to that, how much of a driver was the grocery pickup rollout? Was that a majority of the ecom growth?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Consistent with what we said in the last quarter or so, it's been a significant contributor, but we have not broken that out specifically, but it is clearly contributing to that number in a big way.
componenttext: Consistent with what we said in the last quarter or so, it's been a significant contributor, but we have not broken that out specifically, but it is clearly contributing to that number in a big way.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that means it's the biggest thing, but it doesn't have to be a majority of it? Is that -- I just want to make sure I'm translating the words right.
componenttext: Okay. So that means it's the biggest thing, but it doesn't have to be a majority of it? Is that -- I just want to make sure I'm translating the words right.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't characterize it that way. It's a significant contributor, but I wouldn't start to read into majority, minority.
componenttext: No, I wouldn't characterize it that way. It's a significant contributor, but I wouldn't start to read into majority, minority.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the tariffs, the -- I think Home Depot has sort of outlined, and there's different ways you can talk about it, but so far 1% of their U.S. purchases at the current rates are what's on the list. Are you able to give us something simi
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the tariffs, the -- I think Home Depot has sort of outlined, and there's different ways you can talk about it, but so far 1% of their U.S. purchases at the current rates are what's on the list. Are you able to give us something similar? I think that we go to 3.5% if we went to 25%. I know in the past, you've said a majority of your U.S. purchases are done domestically. So just anything else, Dan, that you could give us on that front.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So 2/3 of our U.S. purchases are made in the U.S.A. We do have -- and part of that just because we have such a big food and consumable business, that's like mid-50s type mix. And then the rest -- the other 1/3 is coming from other countries besides C
componenttext: Yes. So 2/3 of our U.S. purchases are made in the U.S.A. We do have -- and part of that just because we have such a big food and consumable business, that's like mid-50s type mix. And then the rest -- the other 1/3 is coming from other countries besides China. We haven't broken that out specifically, nor have we broken out the specific level of impact that we would expect, but obviously, we will -- many companies are experiencing it. The key takeaway, I think, should be that we are going to manage the margins through this period. The merchants have been in these situations before. We're going to maintain our price gaps with the market, but I think ultimately, it's a case-by-case situation. There's situations where we'll be able to take cost out to offset. So it's not a -- I can't describe it in a really simple form for you, but I think what I want you to leave the call with is that we're going to be able to manage through it. And at the end of the day, when the consumer was stretched on the dollar, I think Walmart has been in a really good position to benefit from it given our everyday low prices.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then last, if I could, on Sam's. I just wanted to get a sense as to the trend in profit being down despite weaker comps. Could you help us understand when we might hit that inflection where a comp of 3 or better could actually mean opera
componenttext: That's great. And then last, if I could, on Sam's. I just wanted to get a sense as to the trend in profit being down despite weaker comps. Could you help us understand when we might hit that inflection where a comp of 3 or better could actually mean operating profit was up?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as you know, when John Furner started to head up that business, he made a lot of strategic decisions to different areas, one of which included price investment, included making investments in the member proposition. This quarter was -- we had some
componenttext: Yes. So as you know, when John Furner started to head up that business, he made a lot of strategic decisions to different areas, one of which included price investment, included making investments in the member proposition. This quarter was -- we had some timing issues with bonus accrual that were probably added a bit more pressure than we would have expected, but if you look at the overall business, we're pleased with the membership trends. We're pleased with the comps. The gross margin, excluding fuel, was up 6 basis points, that was held by reduced tobacco volumes. There was some offset though from price investment, e-commerce, fulfillment and shrink. On the SG&A side, it was really a lot about wages, severance to bonus accrual, timing.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: That's great. So that's -- the 43 basis points of increase in OpEx, the big chunk of that was the higher incentive comp, so like if -- and that seems like it was, I don't want to call it one-off or unusual, but it seems like that was particularly heavy th
componenttext: That's great. So that's -- the 43 basis points of increase in OpEx, the big chunk of that was the higher incentive comp, so like if -- and that seems like it was, I don't want to call it one-off or unusual, but it seems like that was particularly heavy this quarter and we should expect something more normal there going forward.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: That's a fair characterization, yes.
componenttext: That's a fair characterization, yes.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Kelly Bania with BMO Capital.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Kelly Bania with BMO Capital.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a little bit about just prices. It seems like grocery inflation is pretty nonexistent at least in the government data. And so I was curious if you could talk about what you're seeing there, if you're seeing any deflationary categories
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a little bit about just prices. It seems like grocery inflation is pretty nonexistent at least in the government data. And so I was curious if you could talk about what you're seeing there, if you're seeing any deflationary categories and what you're seeing in the competitive environment. And as we think about next year, is maybe there's some more pressure from the tariffs, from some of the discretionary categories. Is -- I guess, do you think it's an advantage to kind of maybe balance the 2 where there is maybe not some pressure on the food and grocery categories, but maybe some more on the other side? And I guess, just how you're thinking about that into 2019?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of inflation, we did see some cost inflation in the food category. It's meat and dairy, more so, some produce, there was some offsets. But net-net, if you look at the retail inflation, that was pretty much nonexistent. As I mentioned earl
componenttext: Yes. So in terms of inflation, we did see some cost inflation in the food category. It's meat and dairy, more so, some produce, there was some offsets. But net-net, if you look at the retail inflation, that was pretty much nonexistent. As I mentioned earlier, that was a function of price investment. So hopefully that adds some color. The -- I'm sorry, the second part of your question was whether or not we would take some of the tariff pressure through price increases in other parts of the store, was that it?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just as you kind of look at the cost pressures, it seems like there is more maybe on some of the discretionary categories and maybe less in the food and grocery side. I don't know if that's accurate, but do you think that you kind of look at balancin
componenttext: Yes. Just as you kind of look at the cost pressures, it seems like there is more maybe on some of the discretionary categories and maybe less in the food and grocery side. I don't know if that's accurate, but do you think that you kind of look at balancing those across the categories or relative to some others that maybe are more in each category specifically and don't have that balance.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So we would not take prices up in food to offset cost pressures in a category hit by tariffs, if that's -- if I understand your question correctly. So we're going to deal with those that are affected by tariff -- the products that are affected by tariffs
componenttext: So we would not take prices up in food to offset cost pressures in a category hit by tariffs, if that's -- if I understand your question correctly. So we're going to deal with those that are affected by tariff -- the products that are affected by tariffs on a one by one basis -- on a each basis, and we'll try and take cost out where we can. We're going to maintain price gaps at or better than current levels, and that's all I can really say at this point. We will manage margins around it though.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And as we think about the gross margin look into next year, I think, the fuel and transportation and freight costs were one of the factors, and I guess with oil prices just coming down so much over the last several weeks, I was
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And as we think about the gross margin look into next year, I think, the fuel and transportation and freight costs were one of the factors, and I guess with oil prices just coming down so much over the last several weeks, I was just curious how that or if that, at all, impacts the outlook for next year.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to pretend to be able to predict oil prices, but certainly, it has been a factor. I think certainly, the driver shortage, the -- has been a bigger issue, the freight piece of it has been a problem too, that continues to persist. So for
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to pretend to be able to predict oil prices, but certainly, it has been a factor. I think certainly, the driver shortage, the -- has been a bigger issue, the freight piece of it has been a problem too, that continues to persist. So for the time being, we're anticipating continued transportation cost pressure.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Oliver Chen with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Oliver Chen with Cowen and Company.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Regarding the upcoming holiday in Black Friday, just open ended, what are some of the features that you think are more -- most incremental this year versus last year? The checkout experience sounds very helpful. Will that be a material transaction driver?
componenttext: Regarding the upcoming holiday in Black Friday, just open ended, what are some of the features that you think are more -- most incremental this year versus last year? The checkout experience sounds very helpful. Will that be a material transaction driver? And then a question we're receiving from clients is the opportunity for the possibility of a fulfilled by Walmart service. Is that something that's entirely possible? Are there any thoughts on your capabilities with respect to that potential just because it sounds like you've been making so much progress with fulfillment and also just implementing so many changes within your marketplace that have really helped drive results?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we had our press release out, I think, it was last week on Black Friday, and so you'll find a lot of what we're doing this year versus last year. Obviously, toys are a big focus of this year. So we've got a lot of new toys both in-store, online, t
componenttext: Yes. So we had our press release out, I think, it was last week on Black Friday, and so you'll find a lot of what we're doing this year versus last year. Obviously, toys are a big focus of this year. So we've got a lot of new toys both in-store, online, there's more space dedicated to it overall for the shopping period. As you highlighted, we've got Check Out With Me, we've got the Store Maps, we've got the new website design this year, which we didn't have last year, so better online shopping experience. The overall assortment, I think, is more robust. So we feel really good about the position. And I think we'll come out on the other side being winners. So in terms of fulfilled by Walmart, we have nothing new to announce today. So I really couldn't comment on speculation.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then our last question, just the ecom growth was so robust this quarter and your guidance for the full year is around 40%. Was there -- is there an opportunity to raise that? How are you thinking about next quarter and what you just printed beca
componenttext: Okay. And then our last question, just the ecom growth was so robust this quarter and your guidance for the full year is around 40%. Was there -- is there an opportunity to raise that? How are you thinking about next quarter and what you just printed because the momentum is on your side? And we just feel like the momentum is more likely to continue favorably.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly, we've seen a nice acceleration now 3 quarters in a row. And that e-commerce growth rate, it's been helped by Online Grocery, it's been helped by a lot of things that we have done on the website, on the assortment, private brand, pricing, I
componenttext: Yes, certainly, we've seen a nice acceleration now 3 quarters in a row. And that e-commerce growth rate, it's been helped by Online Grocery, it's been helped by a lot of things that we have done on the website, on the assortment, private brand, pricing, I wouldn't point to any one thing, but there's momentum there. I think we are certainly against a good consumer backdrop that's helped, I'm sure, us and many other retailers, but if we had anything new in terms of the guidance, we would have said something today.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the dispensaries, somebody is asking me about those and we were impressed by the tests you've been doing there. Will those be in a position to roll out next year? Do you think it's something where you'll see Net Promoter Scores at the same elite
componenttext: Okay. And the dispensaries, somebody is asking me about those and we were impressed by the tests you've been doing there. Will those be in a position to roll out next year? Do you think it's something where you'll see Net Promoter Scores at the same elite tiering as you have for curbside pickup? It really seems automated and seamless and you've made some really nice strides in what you've demonstrated at the Investor Day.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So the Net Promoter Scores have been consistently strong for the Online Grocery experience, both pickup, which is obviously more advanced in its rollout than delivery, but we're pleased with the customer response on both.
componenttext: So the Net Promoter Scores have been consistently strong for the Online Grocery experience, both pickup, which is obviously more advanced in its rollout than delivery, but we're pleased with the customer response on both.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question today will be coming from the line of Edward Kelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question today will be coming from the line of Edward Kelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about click-and-collect. Can you just talk about the impact click-and-collect has had on the grocery comp? I know e-commerce overall had about 140 basis points. It seems like maybe that could be more for grocery, just thoughts there. A
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about click-and-collect. Can you just talk about the impact click-and-collect has had on the grocery comp? I know e-commerce overall had about 140 basis points. It seems like maybe that could be more for grocery, just thoughts there. And then how much of it, click-and-collect, do you think at this point is incremental?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So the great thing about our grocery business is that there's so many different things that we're doing that are allowing us to take share and certainly Online Grocery as a service, one that's free if you pick up in-store which is a pretty compelling valu
componenttext: So the great thing about our grocery business is that there's so many different things that we're doing that are allowing us to take share and certainly Online Grocery as a service, one that's free if you pick up in-store which is a pretty compelling value proposition relative to the market. That's -- it's been additive, we haven't broken that out specifically. But we are confident that it's allowing us to gain share while -- with existing customers but also, importantly, gain new customers but we haven't broken that out specifically, but we think it's significant enough to mention.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Maybe a different way, is there reason to think that the benefit would be any different than what it is for the overall e-commerce benefit?
componenttext: Maybe a different way, is there reason to think that the benefit would be any different than what it is for the overall e-commerce benefit?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So you're asking me if the contribution from Online Grocery to e-commerce?
componenttext: So you're asking me if the contribution from Online Grocery to e-commerce?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I'm asking is the contribution from Online Grocery to the grocery comps, if that -- if there's any reason to think that it would be different than what e-commerce is driving for the overall company.
componenttext: I'm asking is the contribution from Online Grocery to the grocery comps, if that -- if there's any reason to think that it would be different than what e-commerce is driving for the overall company.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think they're 2 different -- that's 2 different analyses, but I can comfortably say it's -- Online Grocery is adding to both, but we've got grocery traffic in the stores as well. So it's not -- I don't think it's -- maybe the takeaway here is it's
componenttext: Yes, I think they're 2 different -- that's 2 different analyses, but I can comfortably say it's -- Online Grocery is adding to both, but we've got grocery traffic in the stores as well. So it's not -- I don't think it's -- maybe the takeaway here is it's not cannibalizing us. We think a lot of that business is new business.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And then just as a follow-up on Flipkart. Dan, I don't know to the extent that you can talk about the management change that's happened there. Should we be concerned at all? Maybe any color on the strength of the bench within that business.
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then just as a follow-up on Flipkart. Dan, I don't know to the extent that you can talk about the management change that's happened there. Should we be concerned at all? Maybe any color on the strength of the bench within that business.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So obviously, we are disappointed that the situation arose. You've probably, at this point, read a lot in the press and we've had our 8-K to refer to. We've taken actions to change the reporting structure and we feel good about the bench. I think it'
componenttext: Yes. So obviously, we are disappointed that the situation arose. You've probably, at this point, read a lot in the press and we've had our 8-K to refer to. We've taken actions to change the reporting structure and we feel good about the bench. I think it's really important that when you look at a company like Flipkart, when you get to that size and that level of complexity, it's not only about 1%., so we've made the appropriate changes and outlined that in the 8-K. Probably I wouldn't say much more than that at this point, but we're committed to India. We still really love the business. We're going to continue to push forward, but we felt it was appropriate to make the changes that we did.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Edward Yruma with KeyBanc.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Edward Yruma with KeyBanc.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, on the U.S. stores gross margin line, you guys have done some changes to ecom changing minimum order sizes or how many of an item you need to purchase to get delivery. Have you been able, do you think, to moderate the ecom drag in the face
componenttext: I guess, first, on the U.S. stores gross margin line, you guys have done some changes to ecom changing minimum order sizes or how many of an item you need to purchase to get delivery. Have you been able, do you think, to moderate the ecom drag in the face of what are exhilarating results? And then second, I think you guys are lapping, in the fourth quarter, the removal of the comanager position stores. I guess, if we just step back broadly, do you think you're going to be able to continue to leverage in-store OpEx?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: We don't comment a lot on margin rates in e-commerce, but we do like what we're seeing in the variable cost per unit. We were fairly clear, I think, at the investor meeting that there's work to do on mix and probably I'm not going to say much beyond that
componenttext: We don't comment a lot on margin rates in e-commerce, but we do like what we're seeing in the variable cost per unit. We were fairly clear, I think, at the investor meeting that there's work to do on mix and probably I'm not going to say much beyond that at this point. You've seen a lot of the smaller acquisitions we've made. You've seen the increasing SKU count over time. We've talked about editing the SKUs online, I think, to the tune of 20 million, added 20 million, reduced, and so we're working towards the goal of improving the mix. And as I said, the variable cost per unit is coming down, so that's good. So I'm not sure if I would say much more than that at this point, but in terms of your other question on operating expense leverage, I think you said in the stores, there's still a lot to do. Stores are leveraging really well. You saw 28 basis points of expense leverage for Walmart U.S., stores were even better. Obviously, that number is affected by e-commerce when you look at it in total, but there is more to do, and I think some of that's going to come through some of the automation that you saw us put on display about a month ago.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Kate McShane with Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Kate McShane with Citi.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: This question is kind of in the same vein as the previous question, but with regard to the Walmart U.S. store expenses and being able to leverage that, how much of that would you attribute to the U.S. comp acceleration versus your own cost control initiat
componenttext: This question is kind of in the same vein as the previous question, but with regard to the Walmart U.S. store expenses and being able to leverage that, how much of that would you attribute to the U.S. comp acceleration versus your own cost control initiatives?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So what you heard from us about a month ago was that the cost culture at Walmart is back. There's a -- everything from zero-based budgeting that we've been pursuing to just getting greater productivity out of associates with the use of technology, th
componenttext: Yes. So what you heard from us about a month ago was that the cost culture at Walmart is back. There's a -- everything from zero-based budgeting that we've been pursuing to just getting greater productivity out of associates with the use of technology, there's a lot of different things that we're going after and there's also a lot of leverage that we can pull in different types of comp environments. I think retail 101one would suggest if your comp goes from 3.5 down to 1, you're going to have a lot of adjustments to make, but that's not what we're planning for. Certainly, that's not where we're seeing in our business. But the things that we do control, we are doing well, I would say, and I think there's more runway in front of us to go after a lot of other items. I think you probably heard Brett talk about a list of 300 cost cutting initiatives on his desk right now. That's a long list.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd add to that is that the stores, keep in mind, that they're -- there was a wage rate increase at the beginning of this year, so they're delivering this amount of leverage despite the fact that there's this incremental headwind. So Greg F
componenttext: The only thing I'd add to that is that the stores, keep in mind, that they're -- there was a wage rate increase at the beginning of this year, so they're delivering this amount of leverage despite the fact that there's this incremental headwind. So Greg Foran and the team just continue to find new ways. A lot of that has to do with inventory management and the effectiveness there. As well as, as Dan mentioned, the automation that we're testing, we're finding new ways through automation as well through process changes to be more efficient, and that's billing us on the operating expense line.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's helpful. And I have an unrelated question, a little bit more specific. We noticed in your management comments that it was called out there's a meaningful price gap versus competitors in Canada. And I just wondered, is that how the comp
componenttext: Okay, great. That's helpful. And I have an unrelated question, a little bit more specific. We noticed in your management comments that it was called out there's a meaningful price gap versus competitors in Canada. And I just wondered, is that how the competitive environment has been for some time? And what is the thinking behind an eventual closing of that gap?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, price gaps are good. I mean, we've been investing in price in Canada as well, and you see that in various markets around the world where we're not only focused on omnichannel integration but also improvements. So I think when we mention price gaps,
componenttext: Well, price gaps are good. I mean, we've been investing in price in Canada as well, and you see that in various markets around the world where we're not only focused on omnichannel integration but also improvements. So I think when we mention price gaps, it's more -- it's to the benefit that we're pleased with where we are and seem to expand it similar to the U.S.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So my first question is trying to diagnose the gross margin a little bit. So as you -- in light of having sort of that hurricane compare on the gross margin, I think it was about 1/3 of the degradation last year, these storms seemed pretty small. So in li
componenttext: So my first question is trying to diagnose the gross margin a little bit. So as you -- in light of having sort of that hurricane compare on the gross margin, I think it was about 1/3 of the degradation last year, these storms seemed pretty small. So in light of that, what factor drove sort of the incremental headwind on a year-over-year basis? Was it the price? Was it transportation costs getting worse? Or was it the e-commerce impact becoming larger as that business accelerated?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So the price investment has been pretty steady. Certainly, transportation has been a growing pressure through the year. I wouldn't say the e-commerce impact was significantly different than last quarter. I hope that help.
componenttext: So the price investment has been pretty steady. Certainly, transportation has been a growing pressure through the year. I wouldn't say the e-commerce impact was significantly different than last quarter. I hope that help.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: And then the Home Depot yesterday or the other day made some commentary about -- some bullish commentary about the upcoming tax refund season, I think they said that they're like 60% of the benefit of tax reform is still lies ahead and that's going to com
componenttext: And then the Home Depot yesterday or the other day made some commentary about -- some bullish commentary about the upcoming tax refund season, I think they said that they're like 60% of the benefit of tax reform is still lies ahead and that's going to come through higher tax refunds year-over-year. Just curious, given your customer base, have you looked at that? How are you thinking about that internally? And is there any quantification or any way you could help us think about it, that would be great.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure. Well, obviously, we pay a lot of attention to the macro factors. We think there's probably been a benefit this year already from tax reform, whether it's money directly in people's pockets or the business -- the stimulation in the economy. We'r
componenttext: Yes. Sure. Well, obviously, we pay a lot of attention to the macro factors. We think there's probably been a benefit this year already from tax reform, whether it's money directly in people's pockets or the business -- the stimulation in the economy. We're not economists, so we're not trying to set an economic forecast here, but we like the momentum in our business. And if tax refunds, they tend to ebb and flow over the years, as you know. Some years, there are timing issues, other times, there's absolute benefits. Clearly, if it's putting more money in the pockets of our customers, we would hope to get that share of it, our fair share of it.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Seth Sigman with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Seth Sigman with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: My first question is around the inventory growth for Walmart U.S. it seemed like comp store inventory was flat. I think that is a change in trend after being down for some time. Is there anything there related to tariffs? Or a function of sales growth? Or
componenttext: My first question is around the inventory growth for Walmart U.S. it seemed like comp store inventory was flat. I think that is a change in trend after being down for some time. Is there anything there related to tariffs? Or a function of sales growth? Or anything else to highlight?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: We said we were positioned well for holiday and toy is a big focus this year. But there's more to do, I think. The level of improvement early on was significant because there was a lot of things that we're doing to pull inventory out of the back rooms. Ob
componenttext: We said we were positioned well for holiday and toy is a big focus this year. But there's more to do, I think. The level of improvement early on was significant because there was a lot of things that we're doing to pull inventory out of the back rooms. Obviously, once you've moved further down that initiative, there's a diminishing return from that, but I think the goal of our team is to continue to get productivity out of our inventory up. I think in this particular quarter, as I mentioned earlier, there's some big opportunities this year that we're going after.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: And there's strong sales growth, so the inventory management is still really effective.
componenttext: And there's strong sales growth, so the inventory management is still really effective.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Right, understood. And then a follow-up question on the online growth, 43%, a little bit better than last quarter. I know it's been asked a couple of different ways but I'm curious more just directionally whether Online Grocery contributed more or less to
componenttext: Right, understood. And then a follow-up question on the online growth, 43%, a little bit better than last quarter. I know it's been asked a couple of different ways but I'm curious more just directionally whether Online Grocery contributed more or less to that total online growth this quarter, I guess, relative to last quarter? I would just think more, given that you have more stores with Online Grocery, so any context on that. And then related, the stores that have Online Grocery for more than a year at this point, and I think you have an increasing number of those, just how are those performing relative to the base?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So your first analysis seems pretty sound. There are more stores with more Online Grocery, so the contribution is higher. Your second question in terms of the stores that have had it for a longer period of time continued to improve and grow. But we haven'
componenttext: So your first analysis seems pretty sound. There are more stores with more Online Grocery, so the contribution is higher. Your second question in terms of the stores that have had it for a longer period of time continued to improve and grow. But we haven't quantified what that maturity curve looks like exactly.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: NPS scores continue to remain really high for that initiative.
componenttext: NPS scores continue to remain really high for that initiative.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Charles Grom with Gordon Haskett.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Charles Grom with Gordon Haskett.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Just on the e-commerce side of the business, Danny, in the script, you guys talked about improving the margin profile. I'm just wondering if you could amplify on that for us just in terms of the opportunity, how long you think it's going to take, what do
componenttext: Just on the e-commerce side of the business, Danny, in the script, you guys talked about improving the margin profile. I'm just wondering if you could amplify on that for us just in terms of the opportunity, how long you think it's going to take, what do you think needs to get done?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So the margin profile is a function, obviously, of 2 things. One, what you're selling? And two, how you distribute it, and we're working on both. We've got sort of head of the assortment that we're focused on with the rollout of Online Grocery, the tail o
componenttext: So the margin profile is a function, obviously, of 2 things. One, what you're selling? And two, how you distribute it, and we're working on both. We've got sort of head of the assortment that we're focused on with the rollout of Online Grocery, the tail of the assortment that we are focused on is to add sellers to the base, getting a more robust set of SKUs and make the small acquisitions in both digitally native brands as well as vertical brands as well as specialty retailers. And we like the direction, but there is more work to do, and we just haven't laid out a specific margin profile by quarter. So I don't know if that helps at all, but there's a lot of work going on, on both sides.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then I apologize if you answered this already, Dan, but I hopped on late. The Flipkart dilution here, is it still expected to be $0.25? And then my second follow-up would be the cadence of the comp and traffic throughout the third quarter
componenttext: Okay, great. And then I apologize if you answered this already, Dan, but I hopped on late. The Flipkart dilution here, is it still expected to be $0.25? And then my second follow-up would be the cadence of the comp and traffic throughout the third quarter.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So $0.25 is the last guidance we gave you, that hasn't changed today. So that's -- nothing more to really say there. In terms of the cadence of the quarter, I mentioned earlier that we started the quarter strong with back-to-school, really wrapped up
componenttext: Yes. So $0.25 is the last guidance we gave you, that hasn't changed today. So that's -- nothing more to really say there. In terms of the cadence of the quarter, I mentioned earlier that we started the quarter strong with back-to-school, really wrapped up that season with solid results as we progressed through the quarter, a great fall seasonal sales relating to Halloween, so really happy with the cadence of the quarter overall.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Chris Mandeville with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Chris Mandeville with Jefferies.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Dan, how are you feeling on pricing relative to peers at Sam's based on the ticket, it would appear that you maybe accelerated some of your investments in the quarter while traffic seemed relatively consistent on both 1 and 2-year basis, but I guess, I su
componenttext: Dan, how are you feeling on pricing relative to peers at Sam's based on the ticket, it would appear that you maybe accelerated some of your investments in the quarter while traffic seemed relatively consistent on both 1 and 2-year basis, but I guess, I suppose, maybe some of that was related to the shift from closed stores. So as we progress into calendar '19, how should we be thinking about that level of price investment going forward? What are your kind of early reads from a return basis?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the ticket is affected by many things, certainly, some price investment. But I think the lower sales of tobacco are affecting it, and we're also seeing more frequent trips with Scan & Go, so a little more traffic, but maybe a little bit lower tick
componenttext: Yes. So the ticket is affected by many things, certainly, some price investment. But I think the lower sales of tobacco are affecting it, and we're also seeing more frequent trips with Scan & Go, so a little more traffic, but maybe a little bit lower ticket on each of those trips. So there's -- we haven't broken it out to a basis point, but those are some of the factors that we're seeing.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sorry, but just in terms of also the level on price investment, how do you guys feel in terms of your price gap today at Sam's versus competition?
componenttext: Sorry, but just in terms of also the level on price investment, how do you guys feel in terms of your price gap today at Sam's versus competition?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So well, we make price investments in different parts of the country, different categories. Similar to Walmart, we wouldn't break that out, but it's something that we like the results from in terms of what we see with retention and membership trends and c
componenttext: So well, we make price investments in different parts of the country, different categories. Similar to Walmart, we wouldn't break that out, but it's something that we like the results from in terms of what we see with retention and membership trends and comps, et cetera, sales. So it's something -- its work in progress, to answer your question.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sorry, what was that?
componenttext: Sorry, what was that?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: That's work in progress.
componenttext: That's work in progress.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then my follow-up would be just in terms of China, you guys saw some solid improvement sequentially on really the overall 2-year as well as in traffic. So any ability to speak to the contribution from that omnichannel event you referred to tha
componenttext: Got it. And then my follow-up would be just in terms of China, you guys saw some solid improvement sequentially on really the overall 2-year as well as in traffic. So any ability to speak to the contribution from that omnichannel event you referred to that took place in August?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Overall, we've been pleased with the results in China. As you've seen, it's been an economy that has seen some slowdown in GDP and it's a very competitive market, obviously, but the .com business, the flagship stores on JD.com are doing well. We're please
componenttext: Overall, we've been pleased with the results in China. As you've seen, it's been an economy that has seen some slowdown in GDP and it's a very competitive market, obviously, but the .com business, the flagship stores on JD.com are doing well. We're pleased with the overall execution. I'm not sure I'd say much more than that, but moving in the right direction.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Robbie Ohmes with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Robbie Ohmes with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Dan, I had a follow-up question on the .com's growth. So for the fourth quarter, last year going into the fourth quarter, you guys had amazing .com momentum, and then in the fourth quarter, e-commerce only grew 23% in the U.S. And can you just remind us w
componenttext: Dan, I had a follow-up question on the .com's growth. So for the fourth quarter, last year going into the fourth quarter, you guys had amazing .com momentum, and then in the fourth quarter, e-commerce only grew 23% in the U.S. And can you just remind us what happened last year? And then how we think about that as a comparison this year or sort of what's different this year, where you wouldn't see that kind of dropoff? Because I think to get to the close to 40 for the year, it kind of has to be close to 40, I think, for the fourth quarter. So it would be kind of similar trends, but last year, the trends were kind of cut in half.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So last year, we highlighted that there are 2 primary issues. One of the bigger ones was the promotional position we took year-over-year. So we basically lapped that in our philosophy around that issue hasn't changed. So the other issue was capacity.
componenttext: Yes. So last year, we highlighted that there are 2 primary issues. One of the bigger ones was the promotional position we took year-over-year. So we basically lapped that in our philosophy around that issue hasn't changed. So the other issue was capacity. We feel good about our capacity and our inventory position today, so I think we're in good shape.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: And keep in mind, Robbie, last year, we lapped the Jet acquisition as well. So sequentially that's where it would slow down.
componenttext: And keep in mind, Robbie, last year, we lapped the Jet acquisition as well. So sequentially that's where it would slow down.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So we should think of it as an easy comparison, not a -- it's tougher to drive momentum in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: So we should think of it as an easy comparison, not a -- it's tougher to drive momentum in the fourth quarter?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, if you break it apart, right? So we're not going to -- we already lapped jet, so that's not -- that was part of the drop, as just highlighted. The other piece was position on promotion, which hasn't changed. So that's not really an easy comparison e
componenttext: Well, if you break it apart, right? So we're not going to -- we already lapped jet, so that's not -- that was part of the drop, as just highlighted. The other piece was position on promotion, which hasn't changed. So that's not really an easy comparison either. The only piece that you would characterize maybe as being easy would be the capacity issue, which I think we've addressed.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So I guess, the first thing I wanted to understand a little bit, I think, at the meeting, Greg talked about competition getting a little bit more intense. It seems as I look at your fourth quarter, you guys have left room potentially to get a little bit m
componenttext: So I guess, the first thing I wanted to understand a little bit, I think, at the meeting, Greg talked about competition getting a little bit more intense. It seems as I look at your fourth quarter, you guys have left room potentially to get a little bit more aggressive on price and we've certainly seen competitors in consumables get more aggressive merely. So I just wanted to see what -- how we should look at the fourth quarter, specifically on the [indiscernible] and how able are you to react if the environment gets more competitive or continues to be more competitive, as Greg talked about?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it varies by market. I think when I look at our forecast, while we don't break out margins and SG&A specifically, I think there's, as I mentioned earlier, there's been over consistent approach to price investment, and I think that systematic appro
componenttext: Yes. So it varies by market. I think when I look at our forecast, while we don't break out margins and SG&A specifically, I think there's, as I mentioned earlier, there's been over consistent approach to price investment, and I think that systematic approach has produced results that we've been pleased with, and I wouldn't expect that to change in Q4. We're obviously going to be very aware of what's going on in the market. We have lots of people dedicated to pricing. And as we've said in the past and nothing changes today in my comments, that we will maintain price gaps and we will be EDLP. We're finding, as you've seen in the numbers, the offsets and expenses to help fund that and that really starts to get the definition of the productivity loop, get the cost out, drive prices down, drive sales and then do it all over again.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: All right. So then my follow-up question goes to the club, Sam's. You have a competitor in the marketplace offering free memberships. Wondering if you guys have seen any kind of impact from that? And is that something you guys would consider or are you do
componenttext: All right. So then my follow-up question goes to the club, Sam's. You have a competitor in the marketplace offering free memberships. Wondering if you guys have seen any kind of impact from that? And is that something you guys would consider or are you doing it as well?

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: No, we have -- we haven't seen any discernible impact. We're pretty pleased with our membership sign-ups and overall improvement in membership trends. Certainly, some of that has been helped by the Plus membership penetration moving higher, which has been
componenttext: No, we have -- we haven't seen any discernible impact. We're pretty pleased with our membership sign-ups and overall improvement in membership trends. Certainly, some of that has been helped by the Plus membership penetration moving higher, which has been, in part a, function of a lot of things going on inside the club to make it an attractive place to shop, but also the value proposition around free shipping with Plus membership, but no, I think we're executing to the plan and it's as we expected.

headline: Walmart Inc., Q3 2019 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Nov 15, 2018
